patterns.title: Environment file detected
patterns.description: Dotenv files often contain secrets, API keys, or configuration values.
patterns.rationale: Dotenv files frequently contain plaintext secrets when shipped with apps.

patterns.title: Backup or swap file detected
patterns.description: Backup files can include older sensitive configurations or source code.
patterns.rationale: Backup files are commonly left behind by tooling and can leak data.

patterns.title: Database file detected
patterns.description: SQLite databases may contain cached or persisted user data.
patterns.rationale: Local databases often contain PII or auth data if not encrypted.

patterns.title: AWS access key ID
patterns.description: AWS access key IDs can grant API access when paired with a secret key.
patterns.rationale: Known AWS key format strongly indicates a valid credential.

patterns.title: Google API key
patterns.description: Google API keys should not be embedded in production apps.
patterns.rationale: Known API key format indicates potential access to Google services.

patterns.title: Private key material
patterns.description: Private keys embedded in apps can lead to full credential compromise.
patterns.rationale: PEM headers are strong evidence of private key material.

patterns.title: JWT token
patterns.description: Hardcoded JWTs can expose sessions or API access.
patterns.rationale: JWT format is distinctive, but could be sample data.

patterns.title: Bearer token
patterns.description: Bearer tokens grant access to APIs and should not be embedded.
patterns.rationale: Bearer tokens may be placeholders; validate before treating as exploitable.
